Award.AbstractNarration:
Languages spoken in the same geographical area share linguistic features; similarities in vocabulary, grammar, and sound inventories are common. Two well-known mechanisms explain these geographically-defined similarities. The first mechanism is genetic relatedness; languages which have descended from a common ancestor tend to preserve aspects of the structure of their parent language. The second mechanism is language contact and diglossia among languages over large stretches of time. This second mechanism has resulted in a number of linguistic areas where language appear similar despite the absence of genetic relatedness. Well-known cases include the languages of the Balkans, Southeast Asia, and aboriginal languages of Australia.

Yet not all cases of similarity between languages can be attributed to shared inheritance or contact. For example, in the African Sahel, stretching from Senegal to Ethiopia, is a large band of languages which can be identified as sharing very general linguistic despite clearly forming several distinct families of languages. The history of this region is deep and complex, stretching thousands of years into human prehistory. While there are proposals that the 1000+ languages spoken here can be grouped into just a few language families, several language families and regions remain problematic. For example, the Mande languages, whose speakers ruled a powerful West African empire for hundreds of years, are clearly grammatically and lexically distinct from the hundreds of languages that surround them.

The proposed project funds an international conference bringing together leading scholars and students from across the world to tackle these difficult questions of language spread and change in Africa. Because the history are so complex and the languages so plentiful, disentangling the effects of inheritance and contact in Africa will form a major contribution to understanding how languages change and develop as well as deepening our understanding of the early history of humankind.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the NSF grant was to fund a special workshop on language comparison and reconstruction. Consisting of Co-PIs Profs. Larry Hyman and Peter Jenks, two postdocs, and nine graduate students working on African languages, we organized and held a workshop on on language comparison and reconstruction in Africa which took place from March 25-26, 2016. The grant allowed funded the travel of several prominent participants in this workshop.

The intellectual results of this work have been considerable. First, the conference itself provided an important venue for people to come and present their ideas and debate the relationship between areal features and whether such features can be reconstructed for proto-languages, as well as several breakthroughs in historical reconstruction itself, particularly in the complex linguistic situation in West Africa. Second, several papers presented at the workshop will be included in the Annual Proceedings of the Annual Conference on African Linguistics, which was held immediately before the workshop. These publications include important work exploring dialectal variation on the Somali-Kenyan coast, exploring variation in Kru languages spoken in West Africa, and a paper authored by Co-PI Jenks with two graduate students on syntactic variation in W. Africa. 

In addition, Prof. Hyman has produced several chapters that will appear in a Paris-based international volume on reconstructing Proto-Niger-Congo which draw on the collaborative work of the project members. Finally, in addition to the submission of some of our work to the proceedings of ACAL, the aforementioned team of researchers are putting the final touches on a joint Cambridge University Press handbook chapter on the typology of Niger-Congo languages. In this chapter we bring together the results of our areal and historical work with sections on the most salient and widespread properties of these languages, including the consonant and vowel systems, the tone system, syllable, stem and word structure, noun classes, verb morphology, sentence structure, and information structure.

Benefits beyond the workshop and single- and co-authored works will also be seen in the doctoral dissertations that are now being written by the graduate student participants. In short, this has been a very successful research project whose contribution is likely to have impact well beyond the grant period.
